title: NDRC Approves Eight Big Projects Worth over 95 Bln Yuan
text:
10.16.2015 17:19 NDRC Approves Eight Big Projects Worth over 95 Bln Yuan Expert says economic planner's green light to road, rail, bridge and dredging projects is effort to boost flagging economy By staff reporter Huang Wenhui 
(Beijing) â€“ The country's top economic planner said on October 15 that it has approved eight infrastructure projects costing a total of more than 95 billion yuan, a move one expert linked to efforts to prop up a slowing economy. 
The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) said work on the three roads, two railroads, two road bridges and dredging part of the Beijing-Hangzhou Grand Canal could move forward. 
China's economy is slowing, and the rate of growth might be lower than 7 percent in the third quarter of the year, said Zhang Yu, a researcher at Minsheng Securities. 
The NDRC's green-lighting of the projects is aimed at shoring up growth because the real estate industry and financial and manufacturing sectors have all struggled, he said. 
The most expensive project will be a 244 kilometer road linking the towns of Weiyuan and Wudu, in the northwestern province of Gansu, that will cost some 37 billion yuan. 
The other two roads are a 96 kilometers highway from Jiujiang to Nanchang, cities in the eastern province of Jiangxi, and a highway linking the capital and Qinhuangdao, a coastal city in neighboring Hebei Province. 
The two bridges over the Yangtze River are in Huangshi and Yichang, cities in the central province of Hubei. The section of the Grand Canal is in the eastern province of Zhejiang. 
The NDRC has said that local governments and companies will provide some of the investment for the roads, bridges and dredging, and bank loans will cover the remainder. 
One of the rail lines will run from Aletai to Zhundong, in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, and the other connects Chongqing, in the southwest, and Huaihua, a city in the central province of Hunan. Those two projects will cost around 26.8 billion yuan. 
On October 13, the NDRC approved work on six other rail lines that will cost a total of 274 billion yuan. 
Li Pumin, secretary-general of the NDRC, said on October 15 that the top economic planner has approved 218 fixed-asset investment projects in the first nine months this year. The total cost of the projects was 1.8 trillion yuan. He said the works will boost the country's economic growth. 
The latest Caixin China Purchasing Managers' Index for manufacturing fell to 47.2 in September, down from 47.3 in August. (A reading above 50 points indicates business growth while a reading under that signifies contraction.) 
The country's trade has also fallen off recently. The total value of imports and exports in the first nine months was 17.87 trillion yuan, down 7.9 percent compared with the same period last year.
